blog.name: turtle-paced
blog.title: turtle-paced
blog.description: Writing at the speed of the race course paradox.

summary: ai-megurine said:  Cersei literally said it was unnecessary and that she would have preferred scaring Bran. She repeated it...
body:
ai-megurine said:  Cersei literally said it was unnecessary and that she would have preferred scaring Bran. She repeated it several time. I repeat: Cersei was against Jaime pushing Bran.

Who are you going to believe, Cersei or your lying eyes?

If truth be told, Jaime had come to rue heaving Brandon Stark out that window. Cersei had given him no end of grief afterward, when the boy refused to die. “He was seven, Jaime,” she’d berated him. “Even if he understood what he saw, we should have been able to frighten him into silence.”

- Jaime I, ASoS, emphasis mine.

In a series that uses unreliable narrators, we have to question whether characters are being honest, even with themselves. And Cersei -

The queen stepped forward. “You know full well, Stark. This girl of yours attacked my son. Her and her butcher’s boy. That animal of hers tried to tear his arm off.”

- Eddard III, AGoT

Tyrion shrugged. “[Tywin] knows that your son’s short reign has been a parade of follies and disasters. That suggests someone is giving Joffrey some very bad counsel.”

Cersei gave him a searching look. “Joff has had no lack of good counsel. He’s always been strong-willed. Now that he’s king, he believes he should do as he pleases, not as he’s bid.”

- Tyrion I, ACoK

Cersei put a protective hand on her son’s shoulder. “Let the dwarf make all the threats he wants, Joff. I want my lord father and my uncle to see what he is.”

- Tyrion VI, ASoS

- is no stranger to self-serving narratives. (See also pretty much everything she thinks in AFFC.) We saw what happened. We saw that Cersei panicked, and in her panic, wanted Bran dead. She said as much to Jaime.

This does not make Jaime any less guilty. In case people missed it the first time.

title: Predicting that Bran will survive
body:
“While being a walking, talking homing beacon for the Night King doesn’t seem to offer the best odds for long-term survival, Bran’s all-seeing abilities as the Three-Eyed Raven give him a unique perspective that may enable the armies of the living to get a leg up on the White Walkers. Not only does Bran possess knowledge that Daenerys, Jon, and their armies can use to effectively strategize against the armies of the dead, but he’ll also be receiving his own personal protection detail to guarantee his safety.Granted, we expect keeping Bran safe to be a taller order than anyone realizes, but as Sam points out in “A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms,” keeping Bran safe is about more than protecting a single person; it’s about preserving the histories and memories of the world of men. When you consider Bran is the sole protector of all human history, he feels pretty safe.“

[X]

summary: Wait hold on, everyone is thinking that Bran is saying the Home quote/speech to Dany or Theon. But, what if he is saying it to...
body:
Wait hold on, everyone is thinking that Bran is saying the Home quote/speech to Dany or Theon. But, what if he is saying it to Jon?

Think about it, if Winterfell falls (actually when it falls) there is evidence that they go to Dragonstone (the home of all Targs since Daenys the Dreamer was like yo, we gotta leave) what if the speech was given after Jon broods some more about losing his home and Bran is just like “nah fam, you still have one, you Targaryen dumbass”

Or maybe the wine is getting to me

summary: So why do you think jaime pushed bran?
question: So why do you think jaime pushed bran?
answer:
Basically a big part of Cersei and Jaime’s relationship is that whenever Jaime decides he wants to have sex, he’ll get it no matter what Cersei says or wants.

“A hundred times I told him no, and he said yes,” the other woman told her, “until finally I was saying yes as well. He was not the sort of man to be denied.”

“I know the sort,” the queen said with a wry smile.

“Has Your Grace ever known a man like that, I wonder?”

“Robert,” she lied, thinking of Jaime.

Cersei went to that tower to discuss what Robert making Ned Hand of the King meant for them. She accurately guessed that Ned wouldn’t just go south without good reason and that his presence would affect Robert. She was worried about being set aside and thought making Joffrey king early was a solution. Jaime, who never had empathy for Cersei, laughed at her worries and started pushing for sex.

“Stop that!” the woman said. Bran heard the sudden slap of flesh on flesh, then the man’s laughter.

Inside the room, a man and a woman were wrestling.

“Stop it,” she said, “stop it, stop it. Oh, please …”

Cersei rightly cared about the political storm heading towards her and as usual to their relationship Jaime didn’t care about her consent. No wonder nearly everyone in the Red Keep knew about their relationship. 

Anyway Bran sees them and they see him.

“He saw us,” the woman said shrilly.

“So he did,” the man said.

Cersei is shrill and Jaime is calm. He probably already made his decision at this point. According to that Jaime stan who blocked me this next bit was Cersei subtly manipulating Jaime into almost murdering a child. 

Bran’s fingers started to slip. He grabbed the ledge with his other hand. Fingernails dug into unyielding stone. The man reached down. “Take my hand,” he said. “Before you fall.”

Bran seized his arm and held on tight with all his strength. The man yanked him up to the ledge. “What are you doing?” the woman demanded.

The man ignored her. He was very strong. He stood Bran up on the sill. “How old are you, boy?”

“Seven,” Bran said, shaking with relief. His fingers had dug deep gouges in the man’s forearm. He let go sheepishly.

The man looked over at the woman. “The things I do for love,” he said with loathing. He gave Bran a shove.

Screaming, Bran went backward out the window into empty air. There was nothing to grab on to. The courtyard rushed up to meet him.

Even if you hate Cersei and you think she’s 100% responsible for Jaime’s actions, Bran was falling and if Cersei was content to let that happen, Jaime was the one who pulled him up, asked his age and shoved him.

This fandom’s habit of blaming Cersei for Jaime’s mistakes and evil deeds while crediting Jaime for the few good deeds he has done is so damn annoying. Does Jaime have agency or not? Why must Cersei be responsible for her actions and Jaime’s too? He is a grown man capable of making decisions. He is not a poor little abuse victim completely dominated by an evil woman for fuck’s sake.

Cersei is shrill and Jaime is calm. He probably already made his decision at this point. According to that Jaime stan who blocked me this next bit was Cersei subtly manipulating Jaime into almost murdering a child. 

Bran’s fingers started to slip. He grabbed the ledge with his other hand. Fingernails dug into unyielding stone. The man reached down. “Take my hand,” he said. “Before you fall.”

Bran seized his arm and held on tight with all his strength. The man yanked him up to the ledge. “What are you doing?” the woman demanded.

The man ignored her. He was very strong. He stood Bran up on the sill. “How old are you, boy?”

“Seven,” Bran said, shaking with relief. His fingers had dug deep gouges in the man’s forearm. He let go sheepishly.

The man looked over at the woman. “The things I do for love,” he said with loathing. He gave Bran a shove.

Screaming, Bran went backward out the window into empty air. There was nothing to grab on to. The courtyard rushed up to meet him.

Even if you hate Cersei and you think she’s 100% responsible for Jaime’s actions, Bran was falling and if Cersei was content to let that happen, Jaime was the one who pulled him up, asked his age and shoved him.

This fandom’s habit of blaming Cersei for Jaime’s mistakes and evil deeds while crediting Jaime for the few good deeds he has done is so damn annoying. Does Jaime have agency or not? Why must Cersei be responsible for her actions and Jaime’s too? He is a grown man capable of making decisions. He is not a poor little abuse victim completely dominated by an evil woman for fuck’s sake.

title: starklings headcanons
body: sansa, bran and rickon tried to raise a kitten together until catelyn rescued it and allowed them to watch her nurse it back to health. the cat disappeared when it was 2. rickon is the only one who loves bathing, sansa does it out of cleanliness and bran tries to avoid it until catelyn chases after him. all three decided they liked the same horse and despite rickon being too small for it, he constantly squabbled with sansa and bran on who got to ride it. usually catelyn allows all three on the horse with a few guards supervising. whenever one of them gets sick, catelyn lets the other two help her and the maester unless the sickness is contagious
